Constructor Detail

SphereHarmonics

public SphereHarmonics(processing.core.PGraphics i_g,
                       int i_phiSteps,
                       int i_thetaSteps,
                       float[] i_preset,
                       int[][] i_colors)
Parameters:
i_g - A PGraphics object where the surface should be drawn in. Mostly this is g, the current PGraphics object of your sketch.
i_phiSteps - The horizontal resolution of the surface.
i_thetaSteps - The vertical resolution of the surface.
i_colors - An array which holds the colors for the vertical and horizontal gradient ([[[verticalColor1],[verticalColor2],...],[[horizontalColor1],[horizontalColor2]]]). You can also use [[[verticalColor1],[verticalColor2],...],null]) to get only an vertical gradient. Note that the the color stuff only work in the OPENGL mode.
i_preset, - An array with 8 floats s
+Example
import processing.opengl.*;

import surface.*;

SphereHarmonics s;
Slider[] sliders;

void setup(){
  size(600,600,OPENGL);
  textFont(loadFont("dialog.vlw"));
  s=new SphereHarmonics(g, 20, 20);
  s.setScale(50);
  sliders=new Slider[10];
  sliders[0]=new Slider(20,50,100,10,20,4,55, "vertical Resolution");//Slider of vertical Resolution
  sliders[1]=new Slider(20,90,100,10,20,4,55, "horizontal Resolution");//Slider of horizontal Resolution
  
  sliders[2]=new Slider(20,140,100,10,20,0,100, "r1m");
  sliders[3]=new Slider(20,180,100,10,20,0,100, "rn1");
  sliders[4]=new Slider(20,220,100,10,20,0,100, "rn2");
  sliders[5]=new Slider(20,260,100,10,20,0,100, "rn3");
  
  sliders[6]=new Slider(20,300,100,10,20,0,100, "r2m");
  sliders[7]=new Slider(20,340,100,10,20,0,100, "r2n1");
  sliders[8]=new Slider(20,380,100,10,20,0,100, "r2n2");
  sliders[9]=new Slider(20,420,100,10,20,0,100, "r2n3");
  
  
  sliders[8]=new Slider(20,380,100,10,20,0,100, "r2n2");
  sliders[9]=new Slider(20,420,100,10,20,0,100, "r2n3");
  
  
}

  background(255);
  lights();
  boolean moved=false;
  for(int i=0;i
